Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Situation2: They notice minor inconsistencies in a building plan that are unlikely to cause immediate issues.
Story:
I glanced at the clock on my monitor—ten minutes until the weekly team meeting. As a colleague, I was expected to show up, contribute, and keep the camaraderie alive, even if today’s agenda was just a routine catch-up. The meeting would be recorded, but I knew my absence would be noticed, and I didn’t want to seem disengaged. 

But as I reviewed the building plans on my desk, my architect’s eye caught a few minor inconsistencies. They weren’t urgent, nothing that would cause immediate danger, but I knew that safety and compliance were my responsibility. If I didn’t double-check these details now, they might slip through the cracks. 

My inbox pinged with a meeting reminder. I felt the pressure mounting—my team expected my presence, but my professional integrity as an architect demanded my attention elsewhere. I sat frozen, torn between the easy camaraderie of my colleagues and the silent, weighty obligation to the safety of a building yet to rise.
